ALLEGATION: Youth A snuck into the bathroom without permission; Youth B
then requested a bathroom break and was given permission. Youth B reported he
attempted to scream but did not. It is alleged that Youth B pulled Youth A’s pants
down and performed oral sex.
Youth A alleged he snuck into the bathroom and then Youth B entered,
covered Youth A’s mouth, pulled his pants down, performed oral sex on him,
and then anally penetrated him with his penis. Youth A had blood on his t-shirt
and was transported to hospital.
INVESTIGATION:
I spoke to Administrator 1 on 9/20/21. Allegations were discussed. Police
involvement has already occurred and will be completing an investigation. Youth had
been interviewed by police.
I reviewed the following documentation throughout the course of the
investigation:
 Patient Demographic Profiles
 St Joseph Mercy Oakland Emergency Medical Document
 Physical Examination Assessment
 Sexual Acting Out Precaution (SAO) Residential Round Sheet
 Observation Process (Level of Monitoring) Policy
 Program Statement
I reviewed the Program Statement:
Havenwyck Impulse Disorder Program is a program for male, 9-17, sex offenders and
abuse reactive youth. It is a secure treatment program. The facility serves youth with
significant mental health issues and sexually impulsive behaviors…
I observed the video on 9/20/21. The video being observed is dated 9/18/21 starting
at 19:46:48.
3

***It is to be noted that the youth were in the hallway completing medication distribution,
showers, and laundry during the time of the incident.
19:46:48: Youth A is standing against the wall, and exposes himself to Youth B across
the hallway
19:48:11: Staff 1 is in the hallway
19:48:31: Supervisor 1 unlocks the bathroom door
19:48:36: Supervisor 1 leaves the area and goes down to Classroom A hallway; Youth A
is at staff desk
19:49:19: Supervisor 1 comes back into the previous area with Staff 1
19:49:37: Supervisor 1 leaves the hallway and goes out the door (leaving the area)
19:50:00: Supervisor 1 comes back into the area and goes back down Classroom A
hallway
19:50:44: Youth A goes into unlocked bathroom door
19:51:39: Youth A opens bathroom door, steps out and then goes back into the bathroom
then closes the door
19:52:27: Youth B goes into bathroom
19:56:13: Staff 2 comes into hallway looking for Youth A
19:56:44: Staff 2 knocks on bathroom door, then leaves
19:57:19: Youth A came out of bathroom
19:57:27: Staff 2 comes back into the area
19:57:44: Staff 2 unlocks the bathroom door
***Youth A was in the restroom approximately 7.5 minutes. Youth B was in the bathroom
approximately 5 minutes. They were both in the bathroom together for approximately 5
minutes.
I reviewed Youth B’s Sexual Acting Out Precaution (SAO) Residential Round Sheet:
Youth B is listed as having “Sexual Acting Out Precautions” (SAO). His level of monitoring
by staff is to have 15-minute checks but also “direct observation” (line of sight) at all times.
(All youth are required the 15-minute checks unless more intensive monitoring is
required).
I reviewed the Observation Process (level of Monitoring) Policy:
When patients are evaluated to determine if there is a need for specific precaution,
two decision points will be made by the physician 1) precaution and will order 2)
level of monitoring appropriate for each patient.
Note: Every patient’s observed location and behavior is documented within 15
minutes…If the patient requires more intensive monitoring than the 15-minute
checks, the physician will order either Line of Sight or Arm’s Length level of
monitoring (with an assigned 1:1 staff.)
4

Direct Observation:
1. The patient is monitored continuously, with a direct line of sight always, by an
assigned staff member, including when the patient is using the bathroom or
shower. There should not be any form of barrier between the staff and the
patient, such as a desk or counter.
I spoke to Administrator 2 on 1/4/22. Administrator 2 reported the policies for the
residential facility are from the hospital program; therefore, the 1:1 is not actually meant
for the residential program. Administrator 2 reported there are not separate policies for
the residential. Administrator 2 agreed this part of the policy will need to be updated to
reflect the residential programs supervision.
CAREHOUSE interviewed Youth A on 10/4/21. Youth A reported he told Staff 1 he
flashed his peer. Youth A reported he went to the bathroom without permission from staff.
Youth A reported he did not close the door the entire way. Youth A reported Youth B
came into the bathroom, and he attempted to scream but Youth B placed his hand over
his mouth. Youth A reported Youth B pulled his pants down and “penetrated me”. Youth
A reported Youth B put his penis in his butt.
I reviewed the Auburn Hills Police Department report.
Auburn Hills Police Department attempted to interview Youth B on 10/25/21 but he
refused to talk to them.
I interviewed Supervisor 1 on 10/7/21 via telephone. Supervisor 1 reported she was
monitoring the youth while relieving staff members for breaks. She relieved Staff 1 for a
break. Supervisor 1 reported there were four youth with on the unit at the time. Youth A
and Youth B were two of the four youth. Supervisor 1 reported they were taking showers
one at a time. Supervisor 1 reported she was standing in the nursing station, so she had
line of sight of showers and the youth in the hallway. Supervisor 1 reported she received
a personal phone call from the nursing station. Supervisor1 reported she answered the
phone. Supervisor1 reported that Staff 2, who was assigned to work in another unit came
into the hallway and dropped off two more youth. Supervisor 1 reported when Staff 2
dropped of the two youth, Youth A was on the side of the medical cart. (The medical cart
was in between Supervisor 1 and Youth A) Supervisor 1 reported Staff 2 took one of the
youths to the restroom and then Staff 1 came back from her break. Supervisor 1 reported
she was then asked by one of the other youths to get aspirin. Supervisor 1 reported she
went to the medication cart and retrieved the aspirin. Supervisor 1 reported then going
back to the classroom to “drop off” a youth with his group. Supervisor 1 reported when
she got back, she heard Staff 1 state, “Where is Youth A?” Supervisor 1 reported they
then did a head count and discovered both Youth A and B were missing. Staff 2 then
unlocked the bathroom door and found the youth. Supervisor 1 reported there were too
many activities going on at the same time (referring to the showers, medication, and
laundry). Supervisor 1 admitted they (Staff 1 and Supervisor 1) should have had more
communication between breaks and completed a head count before break as well.
Supervisor 1 reported they do not have a policy on the structure of activities.
5

I interviewed Staff 1 on 10/8/21 via telephone. Staff 1 was the only direct care worker on
duty for this unit. Staff 1 reported she was with the unit, and they were completing
showers at the time. Staff 1 reported she was relieved by Supervisor 1 for a restroom
break. Staff 1 reported when she returned, she couldn’t find Youth A. Staff 1 reported the
phone rang and she picked it up. Staff 1 reported Youth B asked to use the bathroom and
she gave him permission. Staff 1 reported she was not aware that Youth A was in the
bathroom. Staff 1 reported the bathroom door is usually locked but because she was
doing showers, she unlocked the bathroom door earlier. Staff 1 reported she had to be in
the hallway monitoring showers (by looking into the room) and then monitor the youth in
the hallway and monitor the bathroom. Staff 1 reported if she would have to unlock the
bathroom door, she would no longer have line of sight of the showers and all in the
hallway. Staff 1 reported when they found Youth A, he had blood stains on his shirt and
on his underwear.
I reviewed the Physical Examination Assessment. Assessment concluded Youth A had a
linear tear to anal area.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
The licensee shall have a sufficient number of
administrative, supervisory, social service, direct care, and
other staff on duty to perform the prescribed functions
required by these administrative rules and in the agency's
program statement and to provide for the continual needs,
protection, and supervision of residents.
6

ANALYSIS: During a CareHouse interview Youth A reported that he was
anally penetrated by Youth B. Youth A also sustained a linear
anal tear.
Youth B is listed as having “Sexual Acting Out Precautions”
(SAO). According to the polices and procedures submitted by the
facility Youth B should have been on 1:1 supervision. Youth B
was to have direct observation as outlined in his SAO. Youth B
was to have an assigned 1:1 staff to perform this level of
observation. Staff 1 was the only staff supervising four youth.
This is contrary to the “Sexual Acting out Precautions,” as
described in their programming. Additionally, 1 staff was not
sufficient to provide for the needs, protection and supervision of
these youth as required by this rule.
Technical Administrator 2 reported the policy doesn’t reflect the current
Assistance operational standards in the residential program. The current
program does not have 1:1 staffing for youth on direct observation
status. Policy and practice must match. If the facility is not going
to provide the 1:1 supervision as “Sexual Acting Out Precautions,
it should not be included in their programming. Even if the 1:1
supervision is not part of the programming, it has been
determined that the 1 staff person supervising the 4 youth as they
completed various activities is not sufficient.
CONCLUSION VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4109 Program Statement
An institution shall have and follow a current written
program statement which specifically addresses all of the
following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents
needs, implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of
residents.
7

ANALYSIS: This investigation revealed that two youth were able to get into
the bathroom together and engage in sexual behavior. During
that time staff were attempting to supervise showers, pass
medication and supervise laundry. Staff’s inability to supervise
all these activities contributed to the youth being able to get into
the bathroom together.
The agency does not have specific policies and procedures
around pertaining to how the facility is to provide for the safety
and supervision of youth during showers as required by this rule.
.
TECHNICAL It would benefit the agency to establish a schedule with less
ASSISTANCE activities occurring at one time. This would provide for the safety
of youth as required by this rule. Multiple activities occurring at
once, may hinder line of sight supervision. Because of the
population in the agency, heightened supervision may be needed
often and too many activities will cause distractions allowing
opportunities for an unsafe environment.
CONCLUSION VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
A. It is recommended that the license remain unchanged upon approval of an
acceptable cap.
